questions.question: Longtime prisoner who negotiated an end to apartheid with F.W. de Klerk before becoming president?
questions.answer: Nelson Mandela or Nelson Rolihlahla Mandela

questions.question: Decade in which apartheid was dismantled and multiracial elections first took place?
1960 incident in which police killed 69 anti-passbook protestors?
Popular English sport played on the controversial "Springbok tour" in 1981?
Common name for the Black "homelands" granted sham independence starting in 1972?
Resort that named a 1985 pro-boycott song composed by Steven Van Zandt?
Leader of the Black Consciousness Movement who died in police custody in 1977?
questions.answer: Steve Biko or Bantu Stephen Biko

q3.prompt: Concerning the nation of Norway, name the...

questions.question: Capital of Norway established as a trading outpost in 1048 by Harald Hardrada.
Fuel resource which Norway led Europe in producing in the 1990s due to the expansion of North Sea platforms.
Viking Explorer and father of Leif who founded the first Norse settlement in Greenland.
answer: Erik the Red or Eirik Raude

questions.question: 14th to 16th century "Union" of Norway, Sweden, and Denmark.
Norwegian explorer, the first man to lead an expedition to reach the South Pole.
questions.answer: Roald Amundsen or Roald Engelbregt Gravning Amundsen

questions.question: Nazi collaborator who led German-occupied Norway and whose name became synonymous with "traitor."
questions.answer: Vidkun Quisling or Vidkun Abraham Lauritz Jonssøn Quisling

questions.question: Arctic island, once known as Spitsbergen, which Norway was given sovereignty over by a 1920s League of Nations treaty.
King of Denmark and Norway who fought in the Thirty Years War and lends his name to the old name for Norway's capital.

q3.prompt: Concerning the history of beer, name the...

questions.question: Carolingian "King of the Franks" who established and regulated various breweries in his realm.
Southern German Free State whose city of Munich adopted the first beer purity laws in the 16th century.
Civilization whose city-state of Uruk paid its workers in beer.
French scientist whose discovery of yeast's role in fermentation led to a revolution in brewing.
Flower which flavors and stabilizes beer and which was first used by Saint Hildegard.
Turkish site, containing the world's oldest-known megaliths, at which beer was produced as early as 8500 B.C.
Hellenistic scholar who wrote The Histories about the Punic Wars, including a description of the production of barley-based libations.
Sacred Israeli mountain where the earliest archaeological evidence of beer use was found, brewed by the Natufian culture.

q3.prompt: Concerning the statesman Pericles, name the...

questions.question: City-state which Pericles led at the beginning of the Peloponnesian War.
Epidemic which killed Pericles, likely the same disease which caused the Black Death in medieval times.
Temple situated on the Acropolis whose construction was ordered by Pericles.
Historian who recorded Pericles's "Funeral Oration" in The History of the Peloponnesian War.
"League" named for an island in the Cyclades [[sih-CLAH-dees]] which was dominated by Pericles.
Son of Miltiades [[mil-tye-AH-deez]] and victor at Salamis who was ostracized by Pericles.
Brief war fought over an Aegean island after its philosopher-general Melissus refused to cease fighting the city of Miletus.
Lover of Pericles who Plato suggested was a brothel owner and ironically claimed that she trained many orators, including Pericles.

parts:
(30 pts) This country’s lore includes a “plain of joy” called Mag Mell, and a land of youth called
Tir na nog. One of this country’s culture heroes defends a brown bull from being stolen by
single-handedly engaging (20 pts)

Queen Medb’s [MAYV’s] warriors during the Cattle Raid of
Cooley. Another legendary hero of this country gained wisdom by tasting the (10 pts)

salmon of
knowledge. This country’s folk heroes include Cuchulain and Finn McCool. For 10 points, name
this country whose mythology is described in the Ulster Cycle, a manuscript of which is in its
city of Dublin.

(30 pts) A composer from this country adapted his Lachrimae pavane [LACK-ree-may puhVONN] into the lute song “Flow my tears.” Another composer from this country was
inspired by the horrors of World War I to write an E minor (20 pts)

cello concerto that was
popularized by Jacqueline du Pre [zhock-uh-leen doo pray]. That composer from thsi
country depicted Augustus Jaeger [YAY-gurr] in the “Nimrod” movement of his (10 pts)

Enigma Variations and wrote six Pomp and Circumstance marches often heard at graduations.
For 10 points, name this country, the home of John Dowland and Edward Elgar.
answer: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

parts:
(30 pts) This group’s law code was named after its founder and required the election of a Rat, a
council led by four burgomeisters. This organization fought pirates called the Victual
Brothers and signed the Treaty of Stralsund with Valdemar IV. This organization
established the (20 pts)

London Steelyard as one of its kontores, or offices, which were also
found in Novgorod and Antwerp. This group’s members included its founding city of (10 pts)

Lubeck as well as Danzig and Hamburg. For 10 points, Baltic Sea commerce was once
dominated by what northern European trading league?

(30 pts) Regina Ip resigned from the government of Tung Chee-hwa in this city after 2003’s 1
July March. That march was in protest of Article 23 of this city’s (20 pts)

Basic Law. The “right
of abode” in this city was expanded by its Court of Final Appeal in 1999. This city was the
site of (10 pts)

2014 protests aimed at the ouster of Chief Executive CY Leung that were termed the
“Umbrella Revolution.” The United Kingdom returned this city to its present country in 1997
after a 99-year lease. For 10 points, name this city, a Special Administrative Region of China.

(30 pts) The state of Cundinamarca [koon-deen-uh-mark-uh] was set up in this modern-day
country, whose capital was recaptured at the end of the “Foolish Fatherland” period.
Periods of unrest in this country have included the War of the Thousand Days and the mid20th-century struggle called “La (20 pts)

Violencia.” This country lost western territory when
Philippe Jean Bunau-Varilla helped orchestrate a 1903 revolution against it that promoted (10 pts)

canal-building interests. For 10 points, identify this country from which Panama gained
independence.

(30 pts) Although this river's source is only 150 miles from shore, it unusually runs for over seventeen times that length. The Jebba and Kainji Dams produce power from this river. Its oil-rich delta is home to cities such as (20 pts)
Port Harcourt. The Mandinka people live in this river's basin, which was explored by Mungo Park. Timbuktu, the center of the (10 pts)
Mali Empire, lies on this river. For 10 points, name this West African river that gives its name to two countries, including the most populous country in Africa.

(30 pts) In the 1960s, several of this country’s Christian political parties merged to form the Christian Democratic Appeal. At the end of World War II, it suffered the “Hunger Winter.” Filmmaker Theo (20 pts)
van Gogh was killed in this country, where Queen Beatrix abdicated in 2013. This country’s former colonies include Suriname and (10 pts)
Indonesia, and the United Nations’ International Court of Justice is based in its city The Hague. For 10 points, name this country where Anne Frank hid in Amsterdam.
(30 pts) This colony's soldiers carried out the Pavonia massacre against a tribe which it would fight in the Peach Tree War. The (20 pts)

Eight Men council was created by a leader of this colony who was petitioned in the Flushing Remonstrance. This colony granted land to patroons and fought Kieft's War against the Lenape [leh-nah-pay] tribe. This colony (10 pts)

cheaply purchased an island under director Peter Minuit. For 10 points, name this colony once led by the peg-legged Peter Stuyvesant, which had a capital at New Amsterdam and was replaced by New York.

(30 pts) Nineteenth-century conflict in this country centered on the Bay of Plenty, which was the home of an indigenous guerrilla leader named Te Kooti. Dusky Sound is an inlet of this country's southwest coast, which was a major early center of jade production. The (20 pts)
Otago gold rush took place in this country, whose indigenous people call it by a name that means “land of the long white cloud.” The Treaty of (10 pts)
Waitangi was a controversial land document in, for 10 points, what island country in the southwest Pacific whose capital is Wellington?

(30 pts) In 2007, this country's military dictator suspended the chief justice of its supreme court and declared a state of emergency before resigning the next year. This country's president Pervez (20 pts)

Musharraf seized power in a coup in 1999 soon after the indecisive (+) Kargil War. In this country's most recent elections, cricketer Imran Khan's political party finished in second place. In this country's city of (10 pts)
Rawalpindi, opposition leader Benazir Bhutto was assassinated in 2007. For 10 points, name this country where Osama bin Laden was killed.
(30 pts) The first metal movable type book was printed in this region, which once used a bone rank system. A polity in this region was victorious at the battle of (20 pts)
Salsu River. A kingdom here successfully resisted a Khitan invasion, while a later polity won a decisive victory at Noryang Point through the use of (10 pts)

turtle ships. Sejong the Great is credited with inventing a widely used alphabet in this region, which became a vassal state under Mongol rule before regaining independence under Joseon rule. For 10 points, name this peninsular home of the Goguryeo and Silla dynasties.

(30 pts) Eight members of the Contarini family held this title. People who held this title would board a bucentaur and throw a ring into the sea as part of a symbolic "marriage" ceremony. That ceremony celebrates the day a holder of this title conquered Dalmatia, known as (20 pts)
Ascension Day. Ludovico Manin was the last person with this title, whose holders lived in a palace connected to St. (10 pts)
Mark's Basilica and controlled a certain "Most Serene Republic." For 10 points, identify this title held by leaders of a city-state on the Adriatic Sea.

(30 pts) The Vel’ d’Hiv [vell deev] Roundup in this city collected much of its Jewish population, and Marcel Petiot became notorious for strangling Jewish victims in this city during World War II. Only men were executed for treason by this city at Fort (20 pts)
Mont-Valerien. Albert Speer and Arno Breker toured this city with Hitler, who ordered General von Choltitz to burn it down after it was recovered by (10 pts)
de Gaulle’s Free French forces in 1944. For ten points, name this city where Hitler took a famous picture in front of the Eiffel Tower.

(30 pts) A call for the devolution of this region was suggested by the Kilbrandon Report and was opposed by Neil Kinnock in 1979. The Marcher Lords governed this nation’s eastern border. In the early 1400’s, Henry V subdued Owen (20 pts)
Glendower, a rebel from this nation. The titled ruler of this nation wears a badge with three white feathers, and a red (10 pts)
dragon appears on this nation’s flag over a white and green background. Llewellyn the Great once led, for ten points, what constituent country of the UK whose capital is Cardiff?

(30 pts) Hans Oster plotted a coup d’´etat if war with this country broke out. Political dissidents in this country met at the Magic Lantern theater, forming the Civic Forum. Charter 77 was signed by dissidents in this country, including (20 pts)
Jan Patoˇcka [pa-totch-ka]. Gustav Husak led a period of normalization in this country, which underwent the (10 pts)
Velvet Divorce under its last president, Vaclav Havel. For ten points, name this country that dissolved in 1993 into modern day components whose capitals are Bratislava and Prague.

(30 pts) One artist from this country depicted a Nativity-like vaccination scene and images of poison gas manufacturing in a series of 27 works. Another work by that artist from this country was ordered destroyed by (20 pts)
Nelson Rockefeller. Another artist from this country painted a double self-portrait whose figures are connected by an artery; that artist married the creator of (10 pts)
Detroit Industry and a controversial work depicting Lenin, Man at the Crossroads. For ten points, name this home country of Frida Kahlo and muralist Diego Rivera.

(30 pts) This region was occupied during the Lesser Wrath of 1743 after the Hats’ War. An 1866 famine in this nation and its western neighbor was the last naturally caused one in Europe. After World War II, this country secured its safety by signing the (20 pts)
YYA Treaty with its larger, eastern neighbor, which this country fought in the Continuation and Winter Wars. A (10 pts)

sniper from this country was nicknamed the “White Death” for his kill count and helped avenge this country’s loss of Karelia to the USSR. For ten points, name this Scandinavian country with capital at Helsinki.

(30 pts) This river forms three sides of a rectangular shaped passage in the Ordos Loop and is the northernmost of the rivers whose headwaters are located in the Three Rivers Nature Reserve. In 1642, this river was forcefully flooded to halt a rebellion led by (20 pts)
Li Zicheng near the end of the Ming Dynasty, which affected the cities of Xuzhou and Kaifeng. The tendency of this river to flood, carrying (10 pts)
sediment from the Loess plateau, gives it the nickname “China’s Sorrow”. For ten points, name this Chinese river, named for the distinctive color of its silt.

(30 pts) One leader of this country proclaimed “death to the EPRP” and smashed bottles filled with blood on the floor. Supporters of Lij Iyasu were defeated at the Battle of Segale in this country. Captured British nationals in this country were freed by the forces of (20 pts)
Robert Napier, leading to the suicide of Emperor Tewodros II. This country, which was once ruled by a communist junta known as the (10 pts)

Derg, defeated Italian forces at the Battle of Adowa. For ten points, name this African country, once led by Emperors Menelik II and the Rastafarian messiah figure, Haile Selassie [HI-lah se-LAH-see].

(30 pts) A city in this modern-day nation was the capital of the Idrisid Dynasty and is home to al-Karaouine, the world’s oldest university. This country surrounds and claims the port city of (20 pts)
Melilla. In 1987, this nation completed construction of a namesake “wall” in an arid territory that it calls the Southern Provinces and which is also claimed the (10 pts)
Polisario Front, a Sahrawi rebel group. The Rif Republic was founded in, for ten points, what North African country that administers most of the Western Sahara and whose capital is Rabat?

(30 pts) Victory Polay Campos founded the MRTA in this country. Jose Bustamante became president of this country with the assistance of the APRA. One president of this country was known as “el Chino” despite being of (20 pts)
Japanese origin. The Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement took part in this country’s Internal Conflict. Abimael Guzman led the Shining (10 pts)
Path guerrillas in this country, which fought against the presidency of Alberto Fujimori. For ten points, name this South American country that was home to the Incan civilization.

(30 pts) Operation Fortitude North gave the impression that an invasion of this country was imminent. Ahmed Bouchiki was killed in this country by Mossad agents who thought he was a member of Black September. (20 pts)
Oscar II renounced his claim to the throne of this country, leading to Haakon VII becoming king. This country was ruled by the Nasjonal (10 pts)
Samling party during its occupation by Nazi Germany under Prime Minister Vidkun Quisling. For ten points, name this Scandinavian country whose capital is Oslo.

(30 pts) In what is now this city, Colonel William Shy died defending a hill now named for him. Shortly after losing at Franklin, John Bell Hood’s army was decisively beaten again over two days in this city, ending his military career. A (20 pts)
convention held in this city brought southern delegates together to discuss the Compromise of 1850, but did not advocate secession. This city became the last Confederate state (10 pts)

capital to secede and the first to be taken by Union forces, who arrived shortly after winning at Fort Donelson. For ten points, name this city on the Cumberland River, from which Andrew Johnson served as Military Governor of Tennessee.

(30 pts) The Duchess of Valentinois [val-en-tin-wah] was adopted by a ruler of this country in order to avoid a succession crisis. This country’s highest point is the Chemin de Revoirs [she-min de reh-VWAR], and it built the Fontvielle [font-vee-ell] district by reclaiming (20 pts)
land from the sea. An institution in this country names a set of algorithms for simulating and computing probabilities. This country is currently ruled by the House of (10 pts)
Grimaldi, whose Prince Rainier III married American actress Grace Kelly in 1956. For ten points, name this principality on the French Riviera, known for its casino at Monte Carlo.

(30 pts) An equestrian statue of this city’s founder was camouflaged with sandbags to protect it during World War II and sits on the massive Thunder Stone. An institute for girls in this city was the site of the (20 pts)
Kirov assassination. Nevsky Prospekt is the main street of this city, which contains the Bronze Horseman and Smolny Isntitute. This city on the mouth of the (10 pts)
Neva River is home to the Winter Palace, which housed the tsar from 1732 to 1917. For ten points, name this city, which was known as Leningrad in the Soviet era.

(30 pts) The Morley-Minto reforms allowed this region to have a degree of self-governance. This region was divided into provinces and princely states and garrisoned by three Presidency armies. The (20 pts)
independence of this region was the subject of an agreement with Lord Irwin at a Round Table Conference, as well as the earlier Lucknow Pact. This region came under direct rule after the (10 pts)
Sepoy Mutiny and the dissolution of its ruling company. For ten points, name this former British colony ruled from Calcutta and New Delhi.
q4.answer: the British Raj or British India

parts: (30 pts) Violence in this city was investigated by the McCone Commission. The 1964 repeal of the Rumford Fair Housing Act flared tensions in this city, as did Marquette Frye’s arrest for drunk driving a year later, culminating in 34 deaths in a week of (20 pts)
rioting in 1965. In 1992, a man asked “can we all get along?” on TV days after Stacey Koon and Laurence Powell, members of this city’s (10 pts)
police department, were acquitted of beating him. For ten points, name this California city that suffered the Watts and Rodney King riots.

(30 pts) A church in this country, Our Lady Mary of Zion, claims to hold the Ark of the Covenant. The easternmost portion of this country was invaded in the 1977 Ogaden War. Although this country’s largest ethnic group is the (20 pts)
Oromo, its official language, written with the Ge’ez script, is Amharic. Lake Tana, the source of the Blue Nile, is located in this country, which was once ruled by the communist (10 pts)
Derg regime and lost its Red Sea coastline in 1993. Eritrea declared independence from, for ten points, what East African country whose capital is Addis Ababa?
(30 pts) This city’s downtown is nicknamed for a structure that occupies Van Buren, Wells, and Lake Streets, plus Wabash Avenue. This city’s namesake river was connected to the (20 pts)

Des Plaines [dess plains] River in a 1900 project that reversed its flow. The second star on this city’s flag commemorates an event that started at 137 DeKoven Street. This city’s elevated trains form the downtown (10 pts)
Loop, which is home to Willis Tower. Mrs. O’Leary’s cow supposedly started an 1871 fire in, for ten points, what Midwestern city, the largest in Illinois?

(30 pts) A crucial battle leading to the end of this dynasty may have been fought near Chibi City. This dynasty, which earlier fought the Xiongnu barbarians, was briefly interrupted when the Liu family was overthrown by Wang Mang. The Celestial Masters launched the (20 pts)
Five Pecks of Rice revolt against this dynasty in an attempt to rid the world of decadence. The Yellow Turban Rebellion brought this dynasty to an end, leading to the (10 pts)
Three Kingdoms Period. Liu Bang founded, for ten points, what dynasty that shares its name with the predominant ethnicity in modern China?

(30 pts) The busiest cantilever bridge in the world connects this city to Howrah. This city’s former Dalhousie Square was renamed B. B. D. Bagh after independence. Located on the Hooghly River, a Home for the Dying was established here by the Missionaries of Charity, led by an (20 pts)
Albanian-born nun. This city’s Fort William was the site of a 1756 incident where British prisoners were suffocated in a small room. A (10 pts)
“Black Hole” tragedy took place in, for ten points, what Indian city in the Ganges Delta, the capital of West Bengal and adopted home of Mother Teresa?

(30 pts) To prevent this country from surrendering, the son of its leader was kidnapped in Operation Panzerfaust by Otto Skorzeny. The two Vienna Awards returned territory that this country had lost in the Treaty of (20 pts)

Trianon. Ferenc Sz´alasi [fer-entz sh-lah-zee] replaced Admiral Mikl´os Horthy as leader of this country, allowing the Arrow Cross Party to take power, and J´anos K´ad´ar [yan-osh kah-dar] took power in this country after it attempted to leave the (10 pts)
Warsaw Pact. For ten points, name this country where Imre Nagy’s [nahj’s] 1956 revolution was crushed by Soviet tanks in Budapest.
(30 pts) One block of this city’s Camac Street is paved with wooden blocks. A house on Osage Avenue in this city’s Cobbs Creek section was bombed by the city’s own police force. The (20 pts)
1981 MOVE bombing took place in this city, whose original plan called for five squares, one of which was converted to Logan Circle. A building on this city’s Chestnut Street was the main (10 pts)
meeting place for the Second Continental Congress. The Benjamin Franklin Parkway runs through, for ten points, what city, founded by William Penn and home to Independence Hall?

(30 pts) Catherine Cheynel foiled a surprise attack on this city by Charles Emmanuel I of Savoy by pouring soup on the attackers, which is commemorated in l’Escalade. Jean-Henri Dunant founded an organization in this city after the Battle of (20 pts)
Solferino, and a treaty signed in this city defines the term “refugee.” The Hague Conventions updated a series of treaties signed in this city, home to the International (10 pts)
Red Cross. For ten points, name this Swiss city, which names conventions concerning treatment of prisoners of war and non-combatants.
(30 pts) This city suffered the “Night of the Black Snow” in 1945. The 20th Air Force frequently attacked this city in Operation Matterhorn. Operation (20 pts)
Meetinghouse, which targeted this city for firebombing, was the deadliest single air raid during World War II. A park in (10 pts)

Yokoamicho Park commemorates victims of air raids in this city, where the International Military Tribunal for the Far East was held. For ten points, name this Japanese city and capital during World War II.

(30 pts) Subsections of this archipelago include the Islands of Four Mountains and the Fox Islands. This island chain is geologically related to the Commander Islands, and its indigenous people refer to themselves as (20 pts)
Unangan. Fort Mears and the naval base at Dutch Harbor were bombed by the Japanese during this archipelago’s namesake campaign, which saw the capture of two islands and the only fighting on (10 pts)
North American soil during World War II. Attu is part of, for ten points, what Alaskan island chain?

(30 pts) This country was harshly criticized by the EU after the appointees to its Constitutional Tribunal were abruptly changed by the newly-elected Law and Justice Party in 2015. The perpetrator of the 2016 Berlin Christmas Market attack (20 pts)
hijacked and killed a truck driver from this country. During October 2016, thousands of women in this country participated in the “Black Monday” protests against a proposed total (10 pts)
ban on abortion. For ten points, name this predominantly Catholic country led by Andrzej [andr-zhay] Duda from Warsaw.

(30 pts) One leader of this country packed the head of a rival in ice so that he could communicate with it. Black dogs in this country were hunted down after the disgraced Clement Barbot was thought to have transfigured; Barbot was later caught in person by the (20 pts)

Tonton Macoute police. In 2011, when former president Jean-Claude Duvalier returned to this poorest country in the Western Hemisphere, he was arrested on corruption charges upon his arrival in (10 pts)
Port-au-Prince. For ten points, name this nation that shares the island of Hispaniola with the Dominican Republic.

(30 pts) This event’s perpetrator was aided by Lori Fortier, who helped forge a fake driver’s license. This event prompted Bob Dole to pass the Effective Death Penalty Act. A Pulitzer Prize was given to Charles Porter for his photograph of (20 pts)
firefighter Chris Fields carrying a baby wounded in this event. This attack was allegedly motivated by federal actions at Ruby Ridge and Waco, and was carried out via a (10 pts)
bomb strapped to a rental Ryder truck. For ten points, name this 1995 attack upon the Alfred P. Murrah building, carried out by Timothy McVeigh in an American state capital.
answer: broad equivalents for bombing, like “attack,” after “bomb” has been read

parts: (30 pts) An invasion of this country was justified through Article IV of the Treaty of Guarantee. Voters from this country repeatedly rejected the Annan Plans of reunification. Nikos Sampson was placed in power in this country by the EOKA attempting to fulfill the idea of (20 pts)
enosis. Operation Attila was an attack on this country following the overthrow of Archbishop Makarios, and fighting in this country led to the creation of the (10 pts)
Green Line and a UN buffer zone. For ten points, name this Mediterranean island country divided into zones dominated by Greek and Turkish partisans.

(30 pts) The cameraman Max Stahl helped expose troops from this country who had fired on protesters at a cemetery in Santa Cruz. This country initiated the Konfrontasi standoff to prevent an amalgamation of neighboring states to its west. (20 pts)
Mohammed Hatta helped this country secure its independence from the Netherlands in 1949. The principles of pancasila inspired this country’s (10 pts)
“New Order,” which replaced the idea of “Guided Democracy.” For ten points, name this Southeast Asian country whose president Suharto invaded East Timor.

(30 pts) This man hosted a religious debate at his castle of Azuchi, which he built to defend the capital. He used arquebuses against a cavalry attack at the Battle of Nagashino, and he defeated an Imagawa attack into his territory at the Battle of (20 pts)
Okehazama. After the treachery of Akechi Mitsuhide, this man was forced to commit suicide in the Incident of Honnoji. (10 pts)
Toyotomi Hideyoshi succeeded, for ten points, which daimyo who overthrew the Ashikaga Shogunate, the first “Great Unifier” of Japan during the Sengoku period?

(30 pts) Shortly after this city was defeated at Tebas, its king Yusuf I requested aid from the Marinids to fight the Battle of Tarifa. When this city’s king Boabdil was forced into exile, he allegedly looked back wistfully at this city at a mountain pass now known as the (20 pts)
“Moor’s sigh.” The Nasrids established a kingdom in this city shortly after the Battle of Las Navas de Tolosa. This city’s (10 pts)
Alhambra fortress was captured during the Reconquista. For ten points, name this city, the former capital of a Muslim emirate in southern Spain.

(30 pts) This modern day country was briefly mortgaged in the 16th century to a German banking family whose sons wanted to search for the Fountain of Youth. This country’s city of Coro is one of the oldest European cities founded in the Americas. This country, which was named for (20 pts)
stilted houses in lagoons that reminded Spanish colonists of a European city, is officially a “Bolivarian Republic” to commemorate (10 pts)
Simon Bolivar, who was born here. For ten points, name this country where Spanish colonists founded cities like Maracaibo and Caracas.

(30 pts) These people reached their golden age under Simeon I, who waged successful campaigns against their Khazar enemies. Scholars belonging to this ethnic group developed the first Cyrillic script. Krum, a ruler of these people, allegedly lined the (20 pts)

skull of Nikephoros I with silver and used it as a drinking cup. After losing the Battle of Kleidion, these people were supposedly blinded en masse by the Byzantine emperor Basil II, who then became known as a (10 pts)
“slayer” of them. For ten points, name this nomadic European ethnic group, the namesake of a modern country whose capital is Sofia.

(30 pts) Samuel Sharpe led a revolt in this country against the UK during the Baptist War. This country’s Cockpit Country was the home of the first of the Maroon Wars. An activist born in this country founded the (20 pts)
Black Star Line as part of his Back to Africa movement. This country’s Port Royal grew via frequent use by (10 pts)
pirates like Henry Morgan, but was rocked by a 1692 earthquake. Marcus Garvey was born in, for ten points, what Caribbean island country where earthquake survivors founded the city of Kingston?

(30 pts) Secular and religious forces in this country clashed at the 1208 Battle of Vidines. Thorvald Konradsson brought missionaries to this country in the late 10th century. In 930 AD, the Law Rock marked the site in this country where the oldest (20 pts)
parliament in the world was created; that body, the Althing, was twice led by Snorri Sturluson. In 1918, (10 pts)
Denmark agreed to recognize a 25-year personal union with this country. For ten points, name this country where volcanic eruptions have affected air travel in Reykjavik [rek-ya-vik].

(30 pts) In 1968, a consolidation process in this state’s Duval County created what was briefly the largest city by land area in the US. The 2010 census recorded just 10 permanent residents in this state’s city of Lake Buena Vista, a small company town adjacent to (20 pts)

Kissimmee. Pedro Men´dez de Avil´es founded the oldest continuously occupied European settlement in the US in 1565 in what is now this state. This state’s city of Titusville has suffered economically since the end of the (10 pts)
Space Shuttle program. St. Augustine is in, for ten points, what southern US state whose largest by area is Jacksonville?

(30 pts) This country’s Liberal and Conservative parties agreed to trade off the presidency in a 16-year period called the National Front. The M-19 guerrilas became active in this country after Gustavo Rojas Pinilla lost a 1970 election. In 2016, this country’s president won the (20 pts)
Nobel Peace Prize for brokering a peace deal that this country’s people rejected in a referendum. This country was the base of power of the Medellin (10 pts)
Cartel, which ran the drug trade under Pablo Escobar. FARC rebels once fought in, for ten points, what country led by Juan Manuel Santos from Bogota?

(30 pts) A series of racially tinged riots in this city was triggered by Jos´e Diaz’s death, the Sleepy Lagoon murder. Modern Pentecostalism was developed at this city’s Foursquare Church by Aimee (20 pts)

island. For ten points, name this island south of Italy.

(30 pts) This region's three sacred lakes include Lake Yamdrok and Lake Namtso. An empire located in and named for this region was founded by Songsten Gampo. The activity of this region's Sakya sect resulted in this region's dominant religion being adopted by (20 pts)
Mongolia. Rulers of this region formerly lived in Norbulingka and the Potala Palace in this region's capital of (10 pts)
Lhasa. For ten points, name this autonomous region of China, whose spiritual leader is the Dalai Lama.

(30 pts) This city's lace industry inspired the series Thread Routes, and this city's Church of Our Lady contains Michelangelo's Madonna and Child. Erich Korngold situated his opera The Dead City in this city where the first English book was printed by William Caxton. The site of the (20 pts)
Matins [[mah-TANH]] massacre, this city's Bourse stock exchange was likely the world's first. The center of the 13th century (10 pts)
wool industry in Western Europe and home to the Golden Inlet, for ten points, what is this capital of West Flanders in Belgium?

(30 pts) This leader has been accused of passing pork barrel legislation after having a 4,000-seat stadium built a few meters from his countryside home. While leader of the opposition, this politician staged protests after PM Ferenc Gyurcsány [[FEHR-ents DOOHR-chahn]] gave a profanity-laden speech to his party. This former professional (20 pts)
footballer built a border wall to combat illegal immigration between his nation and southern neighbor (10 pts)
Serbia. For ten points, name this prime minister of Hungary, the leader of the conservative Fidesz [[FEE-dess]] Party.

(30 pts) Frenchman George Psalmanazar pretended to be from this region in the 18th century, even constructing an alphabet from scratch and doing odd habits like eating raw meat with cardamom to prove his foreignness. After expelling the Dutch from this region, (20 pts)

Ming Loyalist Coxinga [[coh-shin-GAH]] established the short-lived Tungning Kingdom in its south during the 17th century. The Urheimat of Austronesian languages is found on this island in the (10 pts)
South China Sea. The Chinese Nationalists formed the Republic of China on, for ten points, what East Asian island?
(30 pts) In this city, a man who removed his shoes to reveal black socks wore a beaded necklace representing victims of lynching and the slave trade. An event in this city was planned by the (20 pts)

OPHR, an organization co-founded by Harry Edwards. Wearing black gloves, Tommie Smith and John Carlos made a raised-fist gesture in this city while "The Star-Spangled Banner" played. American and Australian athletes displayed Black Power (10 pts)
symbols at the 1968 Summer Olympics held in, for ten points, what capital city?

(30 pts) A leader of a "Circle" named for this city, Moritz Schlick, was gunned down by a fascist-leaning former student who took offense to his anti-metaphysical philosophy. While attending the Realschule [[ray-AHL-shoo-luh]] in this city, philosopher Ludwig (20 pts)
Wittgenstein [[VIT-gen-stine]] and Adolf Hitler were classmates together. Kurt Gödel and Otto Neurath [[NOY-rath]] were members of the (10 pts)
Wiener Kreis [[VEE-nuh KRIZE]], a school of thought from, for ten points, which Austrian capital city?

(30 pts) In this region's Gcwihaba [[guh-kwee-HAH-buh]] cave, hunter Hendrik van Zyl [[ZEEL]] supposedly stashed his entire fortune made from the ivory trade. The Khwe [[KWEH]] and Basarwa people, known collectively as (20 pts)

"Bushmen," first settled this desert region 22,000 years ago. Departing from the Transvaal, Boer explorers traversed this region during the "Thirstland" Trek in an attempt to colonize modern- day Angola. In order to escape the genocidal efforts of the (10 pts)
German Empire, many Herero people crossed, for ten points, what southwest African desert's vast savannah?
(30 pts) Henry Clay Work wrote a song about this event, during which hundreds drowned at Ebenezer Creek. Orlando Metcalfe Poe led engineers in this event, which succeeded the Meridian (20 pts)
campaign and was governed by Special Field Order Number 120. "Neckties" of bent rails were created during this event, which ended with a "Christmas Gift" for Abraham Lincoln, the capture of (10 pts)
Savannah. For ten points, name this 1864 campaign of destruction that William Tecumseh Sherman committed in Georgia, en route to the Atlantic Ocean.
q4.answer: March to the Sea or Sherman's March

parts: This politician briefly served as Secretary of Foreign Affairs as a supporter of the Party of Order. This man retired from politics in 1851 to work on an analysis of his country's society in (*) The Old Regime and the Revolution. Earlier, this man traveled to study a certain country's prison system with Gustave de Beaumont, though he developed that study into an early work of sociology that discussed the (*) Puritan roots of one nation. For ten points, name this liberal French thinker who wrote Democracy in America.
q4.answer: Alexis de Tocqueville or Alexis Charles Henri Clérel, comte de Tocqueville

parts: In this non-African city, over 80 people were injured after the execution of Congolese prime minister Patrice Lumumba motivated its population to storm the Belgian embassy. Suleiman the Magnificent mass-deported this city's (*) Orthodox population to Istanbul and made it the center of the Sanjak of Smederevo. Over 100,000 people took to the streets of this city to protest the genocidal regime of Slobodan (*) Milošević [[mih-LOH-seh-vitch]] in the mid-1990s. For ten points, name this Danubian "White City" and former capital of united Yugoslavia, now the capital of independent Serbia.

(30 pts) Jewish people emigrating from this city to Cuba established 24 plants in the diamond-polishing industry during the Second World War. Hellburner ships, which have been described as early "weapons of mass destruction," were used to stop an invasion of this city, taking place ten years after the most violent (20 pts)

"Spanish Fury." The fall of this city led to hundreds of Protestant merchants fleeing to the United Provinces across the border. This city's Bourse served as the world's first purpose- built commodity exchange. The trade hub of Bruges [[BROOJ]] was (10 pts)
eclipsed in importance by, for ten points, which Flemish city?
